fr:ul.fr:li: I have a plethora of meetings tomorrow, so I may not get too much done.
CRL stuff: Meeting with my advisor tomorrow (scary-ish). Will hopefully have next steps after that.
Compilers stuff: High-priority after my meeting. Need to figure out how to get branch counts. Even if super naive (no more CPython rabbit holes).
LLMs stuff: Talk to group mates. Who knows where this might go.

I have added another thing to the reading list: Toutati et al. 2021. This seems to be what I was looking for. A unification of all of the successor-representation-like algorithms that have been floating around my space.
Game-time decision whether I panic prepare stuff for my meeting / presentation, or start the probability measures section of my self-study. We shall see...

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Today we kind of got back on track.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter:
Contrastive RL: As a way to avoid struggling with mujoco, I re-immersed myself in the relevant literature. I had a few takeaways:
I took a look back at the Continual Auxiliary Task Learning paper. I still really want to implement a system that puts everything together. Namely,
In this paper, they do not learn the cumulants that they use to compute the successor features.
Also, is a continual optimizer enough for non-stationary MDPs when learning cumulants?
Regarding implementation details for the Contrastive RL stuff. It seems the first priority should actually be implementing the hierarchical policy.
Currently, the repo is set up to randomly select goals and see how well the goal-conditioned policy can reach them. This is basically the extent of experimentation needed without the hierarchical policy.
I did come across an alternative successor-feature like apprach that I want to take a closer look at: the Forward-Backward representation Toutati et al. 2023, Toutati et al. 2021, Blier et al. 2021. Initial impressions:
Seems to be learned in a very similar manner to the successor feature stuff.
Re-parametrization avoids converging to trivial 0 solution.
Experimentally, seems way better than contrastive (at least for zero shot RL). Weak-to-strong Generalization: I finished up my slides for our presentation tomorrow.
I have sufficiently confused myself on what weak-to-strong generalization even means. Is it
Correctly answering things that the weak model got incorrect? or
Generalizing correct answers on easier tasks to harder tasks?
The former case seems to be the hot topic right now, but I think the second one might be what we actually care about?
Maybe think about how to formulate this mathematically.
